caption: Table 3f - A06: Insecure Design Coverage by AWS Security Agent*
note: * The evaluation was conducted against a sample simplified applications with known vulnerabilities. As a result, additional weaknesses or architectural limitations commonly observed in real-world, large-scale applications may not be represented. Analysis of such scenarios is outside the scope of this research.
rows: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
Covered

Description: The service includes frame and UI layer restriction testing through X-Frame-Options header validation and CSP frame-src directive analysis. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate X-Frame-Options header checking and CSP frame-src directive validation across multiple applications.
CWE-1022: Use of Web Link to Untrusted Target with window.opener Access
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include window.opener vulnerability testing in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of window.opener or untrusted link testing. Limitations: Explicit window.opener vulnerability testing is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface
Covered

Description: The service detects excessive attack surface through business logic vulnerability testing that identifies unbounded queries and missing resource limits. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of unbounded queries without pagination and missing resource consumption controls.
CWE-183: Permissive List of Allowed Inputs
Partial

Description: The service may detect permissive allow lists indirectly through injection and validation testing, but explicit allow list validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Business logic vulnerabilities and injection testing action groups test for input validation issues but do not explicitly test for permissive allow lists. Limitations: Explicit allow list validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-256: Plaintext Storage of a Password
Covered

Description: The service includes code scanner capabilities that detect plaintext password storage through static analysis. Evidence: Code scanner findings demonstrate detection of plaintext password storage in database models and authentication logic across multiple applications.
CWE-266: Incorrect Privilege Assignment
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects incorrect privilege assignment through privilege escalation testing and access control findings. Evidence: Privilege escalation action groups and findings demonstrate detection of functionality accessible without proper privilege checks.
CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management
Covered

Description: The service detects improper privilege management through privilege escalation testing that identifies privilege management flaws. Evidence: Privilege escalation action groups test for improper privilege management in application design.
CWE-286: Incorrect User Management
Partial

Description: The service detects some user management issues through business logic and privilege escalation testing, but comprehensive user management validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Business logic vulnerabilities action groups include testing for user management issues but do not comprehensively test all user management aspects. Limitations: Comprehensive user management validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
Partial

Description: The service detects missing encryption for password storage, but comprehensive encryption validation for all sensitive data types and contexts is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities detect plaintext storage but do not comprehensively test for missing encryption of all sensitive data types. Limitations: Comprehensive encryption validation for all sensitive data types and contexts is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects cleartext storage of sensitive information through code scanner capabilities that analyze source code. Evidence: Code scanner findings demonstrate detection of cleartext storage of sensitive information including passwords across multiple applications.
CWE-313: Cleartext Storage in a File or on Disk
Covered

Description: The service detects cleartext storage in files or on disk through code scanner analysis of database models and file storage implementations. Evidence: Code scanner findings demonstrate detection of cleartext storage in database models and file storage patterns.
CWE-316: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in Memory
Partial

Description: The service may detect cleartext storage in memory indirectly through code analysis, but explicit memory inspection and validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities detect cleartext storage in files and databases but do not show explicit testing for cleartext storage in memory. Limitations: Explicit memory inspection and validation is not systematically performed [UL-006].
CWE-362: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
Covered

Description: The service includes business logic vulnerability testing that detects race conditions through atomicity failure detection. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of race conditions including registration atomicity failures and transaction synchronization problems.
CWE-382: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
Partial

Description: The service may detect dangerous function usage through code scanner, but J2EE-specific bad practices like System.exit() are not explicitly tested, even for Java applications. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities may detect dangerous function usage but do not show explicit J2EE-specific bad practices testing. Limitations: J2EE-specific bad practices testing is not systematically performed, even for Java applications [UL-007].
CWE-419: Unprotected Primary Channel
Covered

Description: The service tests for unprotected primary channels through TLS scanner capabilities. Evidence: TLS scanner tested for unprotected channels across multiple applications. The tool identifies and tests TLS/SSL configuration issues, validating whether primary communication channels are properly protected with encryption.
CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
Covered

Description: The service includes dedicated file upload testing through arbitrary file upload action groups. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated file upload vulnerability testing across multiple applications. The tool successfully tests for unrestricted file upload vulnerabilities.
CWE-436: Interpretation Conflict
Partial

Description: The service does not include explicit interpretation conflict testing in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of explicit interpretation conflict testing. Limitations: Explicit interpretation conflict testing is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-444: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')
Partial

Description: The service does not include explicit HTTP request/response smuggling testing in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive review of penetration test runs found no evidence of explicit HTTP smuggling testing action groups. Limitations: Explicit HTTP request/response smuggling testing is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-451: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information
Partial

Description: The service includes UI security testing through browser automation but explicit UI misrepresentation validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Browser automation demonstrates UI security testing through form field testing and UI element discovery but does not explicitly validate that critical information is accurately represented. Limitations: Explicit UI misrepresentation validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-454: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
Partial

Description: The service may detect external initialization issues indirectly through code scanner and injection testing, but explicit external initialization validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities may detect external initialization issues but do not show explicit external initialization validation. Limitations: Explicit external initialization validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-472: External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter
Partial

Description: The service may detect external control of assumed-immutable parameters indirectly through parameter manipulation testing, but explicit immutable parameter validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Business logic vulnerabilities and injection testing action groups test for parameter manipulation but do not explicitly test for assumed-immutable parameter control. Limitations: Explicit immutable parameter validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-501: Trust Boundary Violation
Covered

Description: The service tests trust boundaries through authentication bypass and privilege escalation testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated authentication bypass and privilege escalation testing across multiple applications. These tests directly validate whether trust boundaries are properly enforced.
CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects insufficiently protected credentials through code scanner capabilities that identify plaintext password storage and weak credential protection mechanisms. Evidence: Code scanner findings demonstrate detection of insufficiently protected credentials including plaintext password storage.
CWE-525: Use of Web Browser Cache Containing Sensitive Information
Not Covered

Description: The service does not include browser cache security testing in its standard testing scope. Evidence: Comprehensive penetration testing confirmed no browser cache security testing was performed. Cache-Control header validation and cache directive testing are client-side security concerns outside the dynamic penetration testing scope. Limitations: Browser cache security testing is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information
Covered

Description: The service detects persistent cookie security issues through dedicated Session token vulnerabilities testing that validates session management and cookie security. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated session token vulnerability testing including session fixation detection. This validates that applications properly manage session cookie lifecycle and regeneration.
CWE-598: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings
Partial

Description: The service may detect GET request method issues with sensitive query strings indirectly through information disclosure and HTTP method testing, but explicit GET method security validation is not systematically performed. Evidence: Information disclosure and business logic testing may detect sensitive information in query strings but do not explicitly test for GET request method usage with sensitive data. Limitations: Explicit GET method security validation is not systematically performed [UL-007].
CWE-602: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security
Covered

Description: The service includes client-side enforcement testing through CSP header validation, Content-Type header validation, and JavaScript execution verification. Evidence: Penetration test logs demonstrate comprehensive CSP policy analysis and testing including browser-based validation of client-side security policies.
CWE-628: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments
Not Covered

Description: The service may detect function call issues indirectly through code scanner, but explicit testing for incorrectly specified function arguments is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities may detect some function call issues but do not show explicit testing for incorrectly specified function arguments. Limitations: Explicit testing for incorrectly specified function arguments is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-642: External Control of Critical State Data
Covered

Description: The service tests external control of critical state data through insecure direct object reference (IDOR) testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated IDOR vulnerability testing across multiple applications. The tool tests for external control of state through insecure direct object reference attacks.
CWE-646: Reliance on File Name or Extension of Externally-Supplied File
Covered

Description: The service tests file name/extension reliance through file upload and path traversal testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated file upload and path traversal testing across multiple applications. The tool tests for file name/extension reliance vulnerabilities.
CWE-653: Improper Isolation or Compartmentalization
Covered

Description: The service tests isolation/compartmentalization through privilege escalation and business logic testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated privilege escalation and business logic vulnerability testing across multiple applications. These tests directly validate whether isolation/compartmentalization is properly enforced.
CWE-656: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity
Not Covered

Description: The service does not explicitly test for reliance on security through obscurity as this is a design philosophy issue. Evidence: The tool focuses on finding exploitable vulnerabilities rather than assessing security design philosophy. Limitations: Explicit testing for reliance on security through obscurity is not part of the standard testing scope [UL-007].
CWE-657: Violation of Secure Design Principles
Covered

Description: The service includes comprehensive business logic vulnerability testing and code scanner capabilities that detect violations of secure design principles. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of multiple insecure design patterns including missing controls, insufficient validation, and improper resource management.
CWE-676: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function
Not Covered

Description: The service may detect dangerous function usage through code scanner, but comprehensive testing for all potentially dangerous functions is not systematically performed. Evidence: Code scanner capabilities may detect some dangerous function usage but do not show comprehensive testing for all potentially dangerous functions. Limitations: Comprehensive testing for all potentially dangerous functions is not systematically performed [UL-008].
CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure
Covered

Description: The service tests protection mechanism failures through authentication bypass and privilege escalation testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated authentication bypass and privilege escalation testing across multiple applications. These tests directly validate whether protection mechanisms properly prevent unauthorized access.
CWE-73: External Control of File Name or Path
Covered

Description: The service tests external control of file name/path through path traversal and file upload testing. Evidence: Penetration testing demonstrated path traversal and file upload testing across multiple applications. The tool tests for external control of file paths through various traversal techniques.
CWE-799: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects improper control of interaction frequency through business logic vulnerability testing that identifies missing rate limiting and velocity controls. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of missing transaction limits and velocity controls in application design.
CWE-807: Reliance on Untrusted Inputs in a Security Decision
Covered

Description: The service detects reliance on untrusted inputs in security decisions through business logic vulnerability testing that identifies insufficient validation. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of reliance on untrusted inputs including insufficient balance validation and improper trust in user-controlled inputs.
CWE-841: Improper Enforcement of Behavioral Workflow
Covered

Description: The service successfully detects improper enforcement of behavioral workflow through business logic vulnerability testing that identifies missing workflow controls. Evidence: Business logic vulnerability findings demonstrate detection of missing workflow controls, insufficient business rule enforcement, and improper state management in application design.
